title: Donna Brazile: In impeachment, the Founders gave us a sacred duty
text:
The founders created checks and balances to protect us. When we protect our nation from foreign influence, we abide by their wishes.

George Washington’s 1796 farewell address contained a forceful warning “against the insidious wiles of foreign influence, the jealousy of a free people ought to be constantly awake, since history and experience prove that foreign influence is one of the most baneful foes of republican government.”

The first three presidents of the United States were deeply concerned about protecting our country from foreign interference, intrigue and influence. You should be, too.

Nine years earlier, in 1787, this fear of foreign influence was on the minds of Thomas Jefferson and John Adams as they crafted the Constitution, with Adams agreeing with Jefferson that they were wise to be “apprehensive of foreign interference, intrigue and influence.” Our Founding Fathers also were conscious of the violent way Europeans overthrew their corrupt kinds, and they wanted to spare our country that violent upheaval by including lawful, civil impeachment in our Constitution. Impeachment is an extreme remedy only used when the president subverts the Constitution and the rule of law, as President Donald Trump is doing by welcoming foreign countries into our elections.

An invitation to Russia

As chair of the Democratic Party in 2016, I witnessed firsthand the chaos unleashed when Russia interfered with and influenced the outcome of the election. It’s happening again, and the sequel is a lot scarier than the original.

This time, it’s not cyberattack by the Russian military with the social media propaganda that followed, it’s the commander in chief of the United States inviting a foreign power to interfere with our elections, with reports of him stating that he wasn't bothered by Russia’s interference in 2016 and would accept it again in the 2020 election.

He's wrong: Trump has no right to confront the whistleblower who triggered an impeachment inquiry

What’s at stake is not just who wins the White House next year.

What’s at stake is the same issue that greatly concerned Washington, Jefferson, Adams and Alexander Hamilton: safeguarding our democracy from foreign interference, intrigue and influence.

President Donald Trump (Photo: Jim Lo Scalzo/epa-EFE)

According to a new Monmouth University poll, only 4 in 10 Republicans say Trump "probably did" ask Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son — despite Trump confessing to having done so.

And, even more shockingly, the poll found that 29% of Republicans said Trump "probably did not" — again, despite Trump admitting that he had.

Our president wants us to believe he leaned on Ukraine’s president because he’s concerned about corruption. And this self-proclaimed “very stable genius” expects us to believe that a congressional investigation into his impeachable behavior is “treason” — a “hoax,” a “fraud” and a “coup.”

Today, we the people need to do our part in safeguarding our principles of democracy by ensuring free and fair elections. We need to pay attention. We need to listen and learn — and believe what we hear with our own ears.

Beware of Trump’s smokescreen and his attempts to distract us from the truth. He would have you believe that what is a question of our democracy, our national security and the sanctity of our elections is just a treasonous figment of the Democratic Party’s imagination.

The American people are watching these proceedings

Nevertheless, this time I believe we the people are paying attention, listening and learning. A CNN average of polls about support for impeachment shows that 51% of Americans favor an impeachment inquiry. Americans understand that our democracy is in peril, and that we must ask all of our elected officials to protect us by protecting our democracy.

Veteran GOP consultant Mike Murphy said recently that he was told by a Republican senator that 30 Republican senators, a majority, would vote to impeach Trump if they could do so anonymously.

GOP Sen. Mitt Romney of Utah called Trump’s actions “deeply troubling,” and Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, said Trump's call to investigate his political rival Biden were “completely inappropriate.” This seems like a small movement, but it is the first sign that senators are beginning to question the president’s actions, encouraged by one of their former colleagues. Former GOP Sen. Jeff Flake of Arizona wrote an op-ed asking “my fellow Republicans” in Congress to not support Trump in 2020, telling them they have a moral obligation “to risk your careers in favor of your principles” and “put America first.” He also noted that “the president's actions warrant impeachment.”

When Donald Trump implied that any move to oust him from office amounted to “treason” and could spark a civil war, Illinois GOP Rep. Adam Kinzinger, a former Air Force pilot, tweeted, “I have visited nations ravaged by civil war. ... I have never imagined such a quote to be repeated by a president. This is beyond repugnant.”

“Republicans in Congress must abandon him now if they care about our country & have any hope of salvaging a political future for GOP,” warned former CIA Director John Brennan, who served five U.S. presidents. “Donald Trump, time after time after time, continues to show how unfit he is for office.”

Impeachment isn't just about Trump: It's about stopping the Republicans who enabled him.

While both Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin make jokes about Russia’s interference in our elections, ask yourself two questions as you watch the upcoming impeachment proceedings:

1. Are the charges true?

2. Are they weighty enough to justify impeaching the president?

At the time the Constitution was ratified in 1788, our Founding Fathers regarded impeachment as an improvement over the violent methods often used in Europe to get rid of corrupt rulers.

Today, we the people need to do our part in safeguarding fair elections free of the foreign interference that our Founding Fathers so forcefully warned us about.

We can’t undo the damage of 2016. But we can learn from it. Our democracy depends on it.

Donna Brazile, a Fox News contributor and an at-large automatic delegate to the 2020 Democratic convention, is the former interim chair of the Democratic National Committee and author of "Hacks: The Inside Story of the Break-ins and Breakdowns that Put Donald Trump in the White House." Follow her on Twitter: @donnabrazile
